awd_titl_txt: SusChEM: Earth Abundant Metal-Organic Frameworks for Heterogeneous Visible-Light Organic Photoredox Catalysis
awd_abstract_narration:
The collaborative research team of Professors Uribe-Romo and Yuan at the University of Central Florida is designing and creating new catalysts that use sunlight to synthesize organic chemicals such as pharmaceuticals.  These catalysts also contain earth-abundant elements, are easy to recover and reuse, and are thus sustainable.  As a result, they are potential replacements for traditional catalysts that rely on rare and expensive metals. These catalysts combine the three-dimensional structural features characteristic of a class of materials known as metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) with molecular groups with high light absorption ability. MOFs are highly porous structures, and this combination allows for shape-selective, light-driven catalysis at superior rates within the MOF pores. The research team is strongly emphasizing undergraduate participation in research, and is also engaging students from underrepresented groups in STEM through seminar series and outreach activities such as scientific public speaking workshops.

The use of sunlight as the driving force in the synthesis of organic compounds is the focus of the field of Photoredox Catalysis. This field offers a promising alternative for synthesis of complex organic compounds, such as natural products and pharmaceuticals, because visible sunlight is free, readily available, and can add the energy needed for reactions to proceed in a sustainable manner. The collaborative research team of Professors Uribe-Romo and Yuan at the University of Central Florida is designing and creating new catalysts that use sunlight to synthesize organic chemicals. These catalysts are crystalline and porous metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) composed of elements that are abundant, inexpensive and reusable (e.g., titanium and zirconium) and organic building blocks that are able to harvest light of specific energies and promote transfer of electrons between the catalysts and substrates. This work is coupling theory, solid-state synthesis, and organic chemistry for the preparation and tuning of the MOF catalysts to adjust their light-absorbing ability, as well as their internal pore structures to achieve pathways in chemical transformations that are challenging to observe in solution. This work is also including activities for the active participation in research and outreach by undergraduate students, and by students from underrepresented groups in STEM through seminar series and scientific public speaking workshops.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.inst_name: The University of Central Florida Board of Trustees
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE UNIVERSITY OF CENTRAL FLORIDA BOARD OF TRUSTEES

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

During the funding period of this award, we explored the synthesis of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) made with earth-abundant elements for their use as sustainable photocatalysts. On one hand, we discovered a family of MOFs that are isoreticular (same net), composed of titania-nanowire secondary building units connected through oligo-p-phenylene dicarboxylate links that varied in molecular size and electron withdrawing/donating functionalities. The crystal and local structure of the MOFs was assessed using high-resolution solid-state NMR, and synchrotron-based powder diffraction and total scattering crystallography. Photoredox properties (light-induced oxidation/reduction) of the MOFs were assessed experimentally by photooxidation of activated alcohols and CO2 photoreduction using visible light, optical spectroscopy, and theoretically using high-level DFT calculations of the electronic structures. We found that the electronic and pore-steric structures of the MOFs had a high-dependence on the molecular size of the link and its functionalization and enabled us to establish design principles for the next generation of MOF photocatalysts with higher efficiencies. On the other hand, attachment of light harvesting antennae groups to organic links in MOFs resulted in the observation of unexpected photophysical emergent phenomena that is only observed in liquid solutions and never in solid MOFs. Attachment of fluorophore groups that exhibit complex photophysical phenomena (excited-state proton transfer and J-aggregation induced emission) produced MOFs that exhibited tunable multifluorophore emission, inner filtering, energy exchanges, and J-dimer emission. The materials exhibited unprecedented emergent phenomena like high color rendering white-light and J-dimer emission. J-dimer is a predicted property that was never isolated until it was observed in the solid state for the first time. Four papers were published in peer-reviewed journals, and research results were disseminated in oral presentations by PIs in the US and abroad.

Broader Impacts

This project produced a variety of new photocatalysts that are made from earth-abundant elements (C, N, O, H, Ti) contributing to sustainable catalysis for transformation of complex organic molecules and CO2 reduction using visible light, benefiting society by the replacement of unsustainable noble-metal catalysts by more sustainable earth-abundant elements. We further produced materials that exhibit photophysical phenomena with applications to societal needs, such as white light for lighting and displays with high efficiencies. This project supported the training of five graduate students, including three dissertations, and eleven undergraduate students. Students participated in research activities and presented oral talks and posters at conferences. This project also supported the participation of PIs and students in outreach activities such as UCF STEM day, US Crystal Growing Competition, and “The Glow Club,” a workshop for scientific public speaking, contributing to societal development in Central Florida and the USA.


Last Modified: 12/18/2021
Modified by: Fernando J Uribe-Romo
